author: Desmater
body:
Energy
Companies not investing into capex but lowering debt, buybacks and dividends. Current prices of $70-85 let's then throw off FCF to buy 10-20% of the float.

Banks and insurance
Higher rates and overall good economy. They have ton of FCF for buybacks and dividend increases. Plus cash to start lending and other investments.

Steel
Steel prices have never been better. EVs, infrastructure and Airplanes need steel. More and more of the world is flying now and growing still. Car makers should start getting chips to restart production. Infrastructure bill in US. EV charging stations will need it. Telecoms need to push 5G globally.

Big Tech
They will always be growing.

Semiconductors
More and more things need semis. I would buy most of them. TXN, QCOM, MRVL, AMD, INTC, NVDA, UMC, TSMC, etc.

author: SnipahShot
body:
While Nvidia is in the chips market, it doesn't manufacture anything, they only design the chips.

I was talking more about like TSMC, Samsung, Analog Devices, Texas Instruments etc.
Intel as well, to some extent as they want to manufacture chips for other companies more.

author: tookme20hours
body:
yeah bitcoin will have to change the reward structure such that larger txn will pay more than smaller ones and miner would probably leave and operations will be more centralised. miners will probably not be delicated bitcoin miners but more general crypto operations. 

the good thing is if bitcoin do get wider adopted then it is likely that the price would be more stable and slightly more payment related txn will be made. mining is probably never going to match current revenue though

author: droptableusers_
body: Texas Instruments is completing one fab in Texas in the next year, and recently announced plans to build another fab also in Texas.

author: TheWings977
body: I thought $TXN was building one in Texas?

author: Ifellinahole
body:
1. Me (34) and my wife (30) live in the USA
2. I am employed making 105k/year after bonuses - regular salary is \~88.5k/year.  My wife is a student with no income but will begin working in July of 2022 making about 60k/year
3. Time horizon would be 20+ years for retirement savings and 5-10 years to save for investment real-estate
4.  We can tolerate risk
5. Current holdings:
   1. Vanguard LifeStrategy Growth fund, not contributing anything
   2. Hartford Global Impact A, not contributing anything
   3. Vanguard FTSE Developed Markets (VEA), not contributing anything
   4. Vanguard S&P 500 Index ETF (VOO), not contributing anything
   5. Fidelity Roth 401k - contributing 5% with a 100% match up to 4%
      1. Fidelity Growth Fund - Large cap, 23%
      2. Fidelity Developing & Emerging Markets Fund, 18.45%
      3. Fidelity value fund, 17.93%
      4. Fidelity  equity fund, 11.18%
      5. Fidelity  bond fund, 9.57%
      6. Fidelity international fund, 8.87%
      7. Fidelity small cap fund, 5.14%
      8. Fidelity mid cap fund, 4.94%
   6. Texas Instruments, ESPP with a 15% discount, contributing 1% of salary
   7. Johnson & Johnson, DRIP account contributing $75/month
   8. 3M, DRIP account contributing $50/month
   9. Health savings account, contributing 200/month not currently investing
6. Only large debt is our mortgage which we pay $2000/month on and have \~286k left on the loan at 3.625% interest.  Cars are paid for and we have no credit card debt. 

My question is about our current investments.  our primary investment vehicle i my ROTH 401k.  Do our current holdings and contributions  look ok?  Once my wife begins working I will max out my ROTH 401k, ESPP, and HSA.  I would like to use my HSA to invest in something, but I have no idea what.  my first thought would be FXAIX but I already have VOO.  Is it ok to more than one S&P 500 index fund?  Should I drop VOO for the for VFAIX?  My wife and I want to have a solid investment base before we start saving for investment properties.

Also, the funds available in my ROTH 401k are very good so I don't believe we need to think about an IRA.   

Any advice will be greatly appreciated.  Thanks!

author: OpticalReality
body:
In order of greatest to least - Nvidia, Apple, Tesla, Texas Instruments, Medpace

Long term investor in all of these. It’s been a good year.

author: Mexicancandi
body: Chip manufacturing is more profitable for new chips but even older designs sell fast. Afaik, that’s what glowflo, Texas Instruments and even tsmc do.

author: GuardianOfTriangles
body: I've been long in TXN for the last 10 years.  Pretty consistent gains with dividends.

author: SnipahShot
body:
>has large government subsidies for new fabs

Just to slightly correct this, Intel doesn't really, at least not in the US.

The US chip act is for about $52b but it isn't only for Intel, it is also for Texas Instruments, Analog Devices (and for what ever reason Nvidia as well).

I don't know how much they will get in Europe though.

And to put it into perspective, Intel's current investment in new fabs is over $220b.

author: missedthecue
body:
Save them from their own stupidity? Semi conductor companies are insanely profitable right now. Intel is shitting bricks of cash, did $6.8 billion in *profit* over the last three months. TSMC printed $5.6 billion last quarter. Micron did $2.7 billion over the same period. Texas instruments almost $2 billion. 

This isn't a bailout, the companies are fine. This is the government trying to onshore chip production.
